item.title: Twenty years on from the Cronulla riots, how have racial tensions in Australia changed?
item.description: The Cronulla riots prompted a national reckoning on racism. How have things changed in the two decades since?

item.title: Russia was banned from competing in Eurovision. Why has Israel been allowed to?
item.description: Five countries have now pledged to boycott the song contest's 2026 edition. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: 'Clear message': Eurovision winner Nemo returns trophy over Israel’s 2026 participation
item.description: Swiss singer Nemo, winner of the 2024 contest and the first openly non-binary champion, announced they will return their trophy in protest.

item.title: Joyce to the world: Our big Political Christmas wrap up
item.description: In the final episode for 2025, Elfy and Rania take a trip down memory lane looking at what happened in the federal election, some of the silliest moments of the year and a certain portrait of an ex Prime Minister Elfy hasn't gotten to talk about yet.

item.title: 'Extortionate': Why fans are calling for an 'immediate halt' to FIFA World Cup ticket sales
item.description: A fan group has sharply criticised the "astronomical" cost of tickets to next year's event.

item.title: The religious minority worried by Victoria Police's expanded search without warrant powers
item.description: Police say new search powers will help fight crime. But how will they affect those religiously obliged to carry a dagger?

item.title: Dark, wet and 'scary': Nobel Peace Prize winner's secret sea escape from Venezuela
item.description: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado emerged in Norway after missing her award ceremony.

item.title: Trump threatens land invasion of Venezuela
item.description: The United States has defended the seizure of a Venezuelan oil tanker as a major US naval build-up in the region continues. Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has described the seizure as illegal with the US also imposing further sanctions on relatives of Maduro and other targetted naval vessels.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 12 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: ASX soars to a four week high as investors eye Santa rally
item.description: ASX soars to a four week high as investors eye Santa rally. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Marcus Bogdan from Blackmore Capital about what's driving the sharemarket and whether to expect the so-called Santa rally.

item.title: Health ministers reject federal hospital funding offer as 3,000 older patients remain stranded
item.description: Health ministers said the door was still open for negotiations after meeting with federal Health Minister Mark Butler on Friday.

item.title: 'Leaving isn't an option': A Palestinian Australian winemaker's fight for his land
item.description: Life for Palestinian farmers living in the West Bank has become fraught, with rising attacks on crops and property by settlers.

item.title: Meet the Australian who's still counting our COVID cases — five years on
item.description: Meet the Melbourne IT specialist who tracks "incredibly valuable" COVID-19 data in his spare time.

item.title: The gift of mobility: How Des has changed 12,000 lives
item.description: A wheelchair can be life changing for people with disability. And that’s motivated a group of volunteers in Australia to turn old bicycles into wheelchairs, for charities worldwide.

item.title: 'Personal blessing': King Charles reveals cancer treatment can be scaled back
item.description: Charles, 77, had been receiving treatment after he was diagnosed with an unspecified form of cancer last year.

item.title: A plan for your home and a plan for your holiday: experts warn to prepare for further destructive fires
item.description: In recent weeks, bushfires have claimed homes and property on the New South Wales mid-north coast, in Geraldton in Western Australia and in Tasmania's east. Experts are warning this is only the beginning of the fire season and anyone travelling for the holidays needs to be aware and prepared when they're away from home.

item.title: 'Everybody knew this man': Trump says new photos of him with Epstein are 'no big deal'
item.description: Democrats released 19 new images of the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey ‍Epstein with several high-profile figures.

item.title: Amnesty International: Hamas committed war crimes in southern Israel
Tom Silvagni can now be named in the press. How do suppression orders work?
item.description: Once known as a 'high-profile' man guilty of two counts of rape, the media can now report Silvagni's name.

item.title: 12,000 lives changed: How a workshop is helping the most vulnerable with unwanted bikes
item.description: From abandoned bikes to functioning wheelchairs, a Gold Coast-based workshop is creating new possibilities for people with mobility challenges.

item.title: Amnesty International finds Hamas committed crimes against humanity on October 7
item.description: As part of its investigation, Amnesty interviewed 70 people, including survivors and victims' families, and visited some attack sites.

item.title: 'Dignified retirement': What happens to the whales left behind when marine parks close?
item.description: Marine parks around the world have closed their doors in the wake of laws to address cruelty concerns. What about the animals left behind?

item.title: These Americans moved to Australia — but can't escape US politics
item.description: As interest in US politics surges and Australians' views shift for the worse, Americans reflect on what it's like to be an expat down under.

item.title: New electric air taxi prototype released
item.description: A company in the UK has unveiled a new prototype electric air taxi, promising to bring urban air transport to the masses. It's the next step in a globally burgeoning industry, for which the Australian aviation regulator is already planning. But there are many challenges lie ahead.

item.title: Two US soldiers and an interpreter killed in Syria ambush attack
item.description: Donald Trump has vowed to inflict "very serious retaliation" after an Islamic State ambush in Syria that killed three Americans.

item.title: Supermarket giants face $10 million fines over price gouging
item.description: Shoppers have been promised a fairer price at the checkout under laws to crack down on purported price-gouging by major supermarkets.

item.title: 'He took all my wages': How visa rules can expose migrant women to family violence
item.description: A Thai woman's harrowing story shows how migrant women are vulnerable to particular forms of family violence.

item.title: Attorney-General Michelle Rowland to repay 2023 family trip as expenses scandal grows
item.description: The treasurer on Sunday rejected calls for Rowland to resign amid growing scrutiny on politician's spending.

item.title: 'Deeply disturbed': Angry fans vandalise stadium as Messi's India tour turns into chaos
item.description: State chief minister Mamata Banerjee said she was "disturbed" and "shocked" at the mismanagement.

item.title: Paleo diets sell the idea of 'eating like our ancestors'. Here's what they actually ate
item.description: A new study by Australian and Canadian archaeologists proves what our ancestors really ate: everything.

item.title: Why Sara and Issam still can't go to Cronulla beach 20 years after the riots
item.description: Australia's racial discrimination commissioner is warning that the factors that fomented the Cronulla riots are still in play today - and that a similar racial brawl could occur again.

item.title: Wanted in Hong Kong, now this China critic's wife is being targeted in Australia
item.description: Ted Hui, who lives in Australia in exile from Hong Kong, described the incident targeting his wife as "immoral".

item.title: What we know so far as NSW Police declare Bondi shooting terrorist incident
item.description: At least 16 people have been killed after gunmen opened fire at a crowd at Bondi Beach with footage showing a man disarming one of the gunmen.

item.title: Mary gave birth to her son in Australia. But he has no valid legal status
item.description: There's a growing number of undocumented children in regional Australia, born to disengaged migrant workers who have no visa.

item.title: What we know so far about the alleged Bondi Beach gunmen
item.description: While a motive is still unclear, police have revealed fresh details about the pair who mounted the terror attack at Bondi Beach.

item.title: Pakistani man falsely identified as alleged Bondi Beach gunman says he is 'scared'
item.description: A Sydney man of Pakistani origin says he's been targeted with abuse by people falsely accusing him of being one of the alleged gunmen in the Bondi Beach shooting.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 15 December 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'Not a blame game': Antisemitism envoy responds to Bondi attack, following Netanyahu snipe
item.description: Jillian Segal says part of her plan to combat antisemitism "can and should be accelerated".

item.title: INTERVIEW: Jillian Segal, Special Envoy to Combat Antisemitism
item.description: Leaders of Australia's Jewish community have condemned the mass shooting on Bondi Beach. The shooting took place as people gathered for Chanukah by the Sea, a community event to celebrate the first day of Hanukkah. 15 people are dead and one of the two gunmen was also killed. A statement from the Jewish Council of Australia says the organisation is horrified and shaken. Jillian Segal is Australia's Special Envoy to Combat Antisemitism. She's been speaking to SBS Chief Political Correspondent Anna Henderson

item.title: Albanese sets 'immediate' gun control priorities following Bondi Beach terror attack
item.description: A crackdown on 3D-printed weapons and firearm limits has been flagged, and citizenship requirements for ownership could also be examined.

item.title: These are the victims of the Bondi Beach terror attack
item.description: Funerals have commenced for the 15 people killed in a terror attack at Bondi Beach.

item.title: These are the victims of the Bondi Beach terror attack
item.description: Funerals have commenced for the 15 people killed in a terror attack at Bondi Beach.

item.title: Hong Kong court convicts pro-democracy tycoon Jimmy Lai in national security trial
item.description: The Australian government said it was "deeply concerned by the guilty verdict handed down to Jimmy Lai in Hong Kong".

item.title: Which supermarket has the cheapest groceries? Choice reveals its latest price check
item.description: There's one supermarket where a basket of groceries is significantly cheaper than its competitors, according to a new survey.

item.title: Albanese visits 'humble' Ahmed Al-Ahmed after Bondi hero speaks from hospital
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has visited Bondi hero Ahmed Al-Ahmed in hospital, calling him the "best of our country".

item.title: INTERVIEW: What needs to be done about our gun laws?
item.description: The Bondi Beach shooting has seen state, territory and federal politicians agree that Australia's already stringent gun laws need to be reviewed and strengthened. The National Firearms Agreement was introduced after the 1996 Port Arthur massacre to standardise rules about who could own a gun - and why. But experts on firearms legislation say some holes in the rules have become apparent. In New South Wales, applications to have a firearms licence are handled by the Gun Registry - which came under intense scrutiny after a tragic murder suicide in 2018, when an estranged father, John Edwards, fatally shot his teenage children. He had a history of domestic violence which hadn't been flagged to the Gun Registry. Not all the changes recommended after the Edwards inquest have been implemented. Deborah Groarke spoke to Maya Arguello who's a law and criminology expert at the Swinburne University of Technology.

item.title: More details emerge about Islamic State group links of Bondi gunmen

item.description: Trump mocked Rob Reiner in a social media post after the director-actor and his wife Michele were found dead.

item.title: Opposition puts migration policy on ice after Bondi Beach massacre
item.description: The Opposition will instead prioritise the formation of an antisemitism and counter-terrorism taskforce.

item.title: Amandeep ate a kebab as the sun set — then helped stop one of the alleged Bondi shooters
item.description: One of the many heroes who sprang into action after Sunday's attack says "now, more than ever, we need each other".

item.description: Chris Booy works three jobs. Despite this, he says that the Great Australian Dream of owning a home is feeling increasingly out of reach.

item.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers said he took his predecessor's views "seriously" and the government would "take suggestions from him".

item.title: The self-proclaimed Islamic State group is active globally. Where is it located now?
item.description: Two flags linked to the self-proclaimed Islamic State group were found in the car used by the alleged shooters during Sunday's attack at Bondi Beach.

item.title: MYEFO inflation implications & Westpac cancels 2026 rate cut call
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Shane Oliver from AMP about the implications the government's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook will have on inflation as Kyle Rodda from Capital.com looks through the day's sharemarket action including Westpac's change of heart on interest rates

item.title: Government deficit figure has improved, but fiscal restraint important
item.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has unveiled a mid-year budget update marked by fiscal restraint, highlighting a $5.4 billion improvement to the deficit alongside critical new funding for the CSIRO and community security. However, the outlook remains fraught as rising inflation threatens real wage growth and persistent spending pressures in childcare and the NDIS continue to squeeze the bottom line.

item.title: How does your day compare? Here's how Australians are spending their time
item.description: Almost 10,700 Australians were surveyed, revealing both insights and disparities in daily life.

item.title: Cricket shirts and fake Hanson quotes: How false information spread after the Bondi attack
item.description: Misinformation and disinformation have been circulated widely since Sunday's massacre.

item.description: Misinformation and disinformation have been circulated widely since Sunday's massacre.

item.title: Nick Reiner's three-word remark as he appears in court on murder charges
item.description: If convicted as charged, Nick Reiner would face life in prison without the possibility of parole, or the ‍death penalty.

item.title: Nick Reiner's three-word remark as he appears in court on murder charges
item.description: If convicted as charged, Nick Reiner would face life in prison without the possibility of parole, or the ‍death penalty.

item.title: 'Allow the tears to come': dealing with grief after Bondi
item.description: In the wake of the Bondi beach tragedy last weekend, Sydney has welcomed new mental health support systems. New South Wales Health is offering support for anyone affected - both directly and indirectly.

item.title: Discrimination concerns as government flags migration reform after Bondi attack
item.description: As part of its response to the Bondi Beach attack, which claimed 15 lives, the government will review its migration settings.

item.title: Albanese 'failed to act' on antisemitism Ley says, as government proposes new laws
item.description: The government will accept a report from the antisemitism envoy in full and introduce a raft of new laws in the wake of the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 18 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Coping with grief after the Bondi Beach massacre: What can help in the days after tragedy
item.description: Experts say the Bondi Beach shooting can affect many, as the nervous system struggles to distinguish between perceived and actual trauma.

item.title: PM introduces laws to crack down on hate speech following Bondi terrorist attack
item.description: In the wake of the Bondi Beach terrorist attack over the weekend, the Albanese government is fast-tracking a suite of legislative reforms aimed at cracking down on hate speech and tightening migration laws to avert individuals with extremist views. While the government faces pressure to introduce harsher border policies, it has rejected calls for a Royal Commission, arguing that immediate executive action and enforcement are more urgent than a lengthy public inquiry.

item.title: Australia's Christmas weather forecast has landed. Here's what to expect in your city
item.description: Before you plan a big Christmas lunch outdoors, it might be a good idea to see what the weather is looking like in your city this 25 December.

item.title: Terror at Bondi, Fragile Hope in Ukraine & Trump’s ‘WMD’ Gamble
item.description: Terror strikes the iconic sands of Bondi Beach, sending shockwaves through Australia and Jewish communities worldwide - how did the deadly attack unfold, and what does it mean for national security? Plus, Volodymyr Zelenskyy signals cautious optimism in high-stakes Ukraine peace talks but is a deal with Russia any closer? And Donald Trump brands fentanyl a ‘weapon of mass destruction’ as tensions escalate with Venezuela.

item.title: Woodside's CEO leaves for BP
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Henry Jennings from Marcus Today about the day's sharemarket action including Woodside CEO Meg O'Neill leaving for BP.

item.title: Environmental laws not settled yet
item.description: Environment and business groups says work has just begun to ensure Australia's environment laws are more effective in practice. Parliament passed the first major overhaul in two decades this year, but stakeholders say the devil may be in the detail.

item.title: AFP target 'hate preachers'
Fears of further financial pain for Australians after major banks' forecasting
item.description: The 'big four' banks have dismissed the possibility of a rate cut in 2026, raising concerns about "renewed talk" of a cost of living crisis.

item.title: The secret to a cooler home could already be sitting in your living room
item.description: Experts share how to keep cool this summer — smart home hacks, indoor greenery and safe spots for your pets, without breaking the bank.

item.description: In this bulletin, Jewish leaders describe the Prime Minister's anti-Semitism plan as "first step"; a doctor jailed in France for poisoning patients; and in sport, the National Rugby League bans major player agents in end-of-year sanctions.

item.title: European leaders opt for loans over plan to use frozen Russian assets for Ukraine
item.description: The decision followed hours of discussions among leaders on the technical details of an unprecedented loan based on frozen Russian assets.

item.title: More than 1,000 civilians killed in raid on Sudanese displacement camp, UN finds
item.description: A UN report has found 1,000 civilians were killed when a Sudanese paramilitary group overran a famine-stricken Darfur displacement camp.

item.description: A day of reflection will take place this Sunday, while a national day of mourning will be held in the new year, the prime minister announced.

item.title: Albanese announces gun buyback scheme as NSW moves on gun limits, protest bans
item.description: Anthony Albanese said he expects "hundreds of thousands" of guns to be collected and destroyed through the scheme.

item.title: Europe assesses risks: Using frozen Russian assets for Ukraine's war funding
item.description: European Union leaders are facing a critical decision on whether they should use frozen Russian assets to finance more support for Ukraine's war effort.

item.title: Bondi hero Ahmed Al-Ahmed asks if he deserves $2.5 million donation
item.description: The shop owner called for unity, amid concerns over social cohesion between Australia's many communities in the wake of Bondi Beach attack.

item.description: Police responded to almost 200 teens who swarmed a local supermarket and beach in Victoria.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 19 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Gun buyback scheme to be established; Sunday will be a national day of reflection
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says his government will establish a new national gun buyback scheme, following the terror attack at Bondi Beach last Sunday. And this Sunday will see a nationwide day of reflection to remember the victims of the shooting.

item.title: Global interest rate moves influences markets
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Mahjabeen Zaman fron ANZ as the UK cuts interest rates, Japan raises them and US inflation eases more than expected, lifting the prospect of lower rates there.

item.title: The awkward new rules about to kick in for travellers to Bali
item.description: Although most tourists are unlikely to fall afoul of incoming Indonesian laws, the Australian government has warned Australians about the changes.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Wentworth MP Allegra MP says the Jewish community has been failed by Government
item.description: Allegra Spender is the independent MP representing the federal electorate of Wentworth that takes in Bondi, the scene of last Sunday's terror attack. She says she and the government have failed the Jewish Australian community and they should be moving faster to prevent hate speech. She's been speaking with SBS's Anton Enus.

item.title: 'Australia is not exempt': The global events that left Australia vulnerable to terrorism
item.description: In the wake of the Bondi Beach terror attack, many Australians are wondering what led to the massacre.

item.title: 'It's safe now': Chinese student recounts Bondi lifeguard rescue as gunshots rang out
item.description: Levi Xu was forced to make a choice: either face the risk of being shot, or drown.

item.title: Ben hasn't seen his loved ones for 13 years. This Australian bakery offered him a job and a new ‘family’
item.description: Refugees and asylum seekers face long-term barriers to employment. Some find their first job with one of Australia's 12-thousand social enterprises.

item.title: 2025: A good year for wildlife conservation
item.description: From former poachers now protecting endangered species to farmers adapting crops and traditions to help local wildlife, 2025 has been a brighter year for conservationists and the world's wildlife.

item.title: 'Huge range of emotions' spill out as Allegra Spender targeted in tense exchange at Bondi
item.description: The independent MP was fiercely criticised by a man in Bondi who accused her of failing to do enough to combat anti-Jewish hate.

item.title: 'We're changing lives': This small Sydney bakery gave Ben more than a job
item.description: At a small bakery in Sydney, asylum seekers and refugees find more than work — they find hope, belonging and a chance to rebuild their lives.

item.description: Anthony Albanese suggested he would support a royal commission into the Bondi attack if the NSW government does.

item.title: What we do and don't know about the alleged Bondi gunmen's time in the Philippines
item.description: What authorities have not confirmed, and may never fully uncover, is what they did while there.

item.title: United States launches retaliatory strikes against IS group targets in Syria
item.description: The ‍Syrian government fully supported the United States' strikes against IS group targets in Syria, US President Donald Trump said.

item.title: 'It can ruin someone's life': The community vilified by Bondi attack misinformation
item.description: Some Pakistani Australians say the false identification of one of the alleged Bondi attackers has had a serious impact on their lives.

item.title: From fringe to frontline: How Australia's far right gained mainstream attention in 2025
item.description: From extremist fringes to the Senate, the far-right opportunistically dug their claws into Australian society and discourse this year.

item.title: Santa, elves under pressure as Christmas Eve nears
item.description: As Christmas Eve fast approaches, Santa and his elves are putting the finishing touches on festive preparations at Santa Claus Village in Finnish Lapland. The Arctic Circle outpost is buzzing with holiday magic as Santa delivers his verdict on naughty and nice, and shares a message of kindness and peace for the holiday season ahead.

item.title: In Switzerland, some workers commute by floating down a river. Could Australians do the same?
item.description: Swiss workers and families swim in city rivers during summer. Could greater access to urban swimming be on the cards for Australians?

item.title: What is Denmark's not-so-secret recipe for happiness?
item.description: Denmark has been ranked among the 'happiest' countries in the world for more than a decade. Some experts suggest this is due to a focus on learning compassion, empathy and human connection at an early age, which supports positive inter-personal relations and conflict resolution in adulthood.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Can early education make your children happy adults?
item.description: Jessica Joelle Alexander is a parenting expert, author and cultural researcher, with a specific expertise in the Danish parenting approach. Alexander is also the co-founder of 'Raising Digital Citizens', which aims to support families to have conversations around values in the online space. Denmark has been ranked among the 'happiest' countries in the world for more than a decade and a big part of this ranking has been linked to learning empathy from a young age. Her books and research explores this concept - and how parents can foster compassion, resilience, emotional-intelligence and human connection from an early age.

item.title: 'We're with you': How collective grief is experienced following the Bondi terror attack
item.description: Collective grief is a common experience, following a mass tragedy like the one Australia bore witness to at Bondi Beach. Fifteen people were killed in the terror attack, and ever since there's been an outpouring of grief across Australia and around the world, especially among Jewish communities who were targeted in the attack. Rituals play an important role in the Jewish community, and experts say they are an essential part of the grieving process.

item.title: Jamie followed his dad's 14,000km England-to-Australia bike ride — here's how it went
item.description: Jamie Hargreaves retraces his father's 1984 journey from England to Australia, adapting the route across Europe and Asia.

item.title: PM orders review into federal police and intelligence agencies after Bondi terror attack
item.description: The review will examine whether the agencies "have the right powers, structures, processes and sharing arrangements in place".

item.title: 'People are raging': Trump facing backlash from within over Epstein file redactions
item.description: A limited release of the Epstein files has angered Republicans and Democrats alike.

item.title: 'Under-16 refugees': Will this platform see another new wave of users after the social media ban?
item.description: With under-16s now excluded from many of their favourite social media apps, alternative platforms remain available, especially for bilingual teens.

item.title: 'It started out as a joke': Why NRL star Mitch Kenny got into birdwatching
item.description: The quiet pastime of birdwatching is taking flight online, linking enthusiasts beyond the outdoors.

item.title: From 'unashamedly political' to 'really steamy': 30 books to add to your summer reading list
item.description: The powerful storytelling of culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) writers is on full display in SBS' first summer reading guide.

item.title: How the Bondi Beach terror attack could change protest laws
item.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns says protests are "unleashing forces" organisers can't control, but critics say the proposals are an overreach.

item.title: Mandy thought she had a gastro bug. Three days later, she was in an induced coma
item.description: For some people who have experienced life-threatening situations, it's not the situation itself that has the longest-lasting impact — it's the aftermath.

item.title: Israel approves 19 new West Bank settlements aimed at 'blocking' a Palestinian state
item.description: Israel said the 19 newly approved settlements are located in what it described as "highly strategic" areas.

item.title: Predictable policies and shock results: looking back at 2025 in politics
item.description: For Australian politics in 2025, it was a year of predictable policies - and shock results. That included the May election that saw Labor win back government in a landslide, and two separate party leaders - Peter Dutton and Adam Bandt - lose their seats. We back at the year in Canberra.

item.title: They prosecuted the Capitol rioters. Now the rioters and the DOJ are after them
item.description: .The Capitol riot in January 2021 set off the largest criminal investigation in the Justice Department’s history. On his first day back in office, US President Donald Trump granted clemency to every criminally charged January 6 rioter. Now, prosecutors who handled Capitol riot cases face a new threat: Justice Department officials advising how to pursue — and perhaps prosecute — the very prosecutors who helped put them behind bars.

item.title: US coast guard in 'pursuit' of another oil tanker near Venezuela
item.description: The first oil tanker was seized by US forces on 10 December and a second one was "apprehended" on 20 December.

item.title: Nation holds a day of reflection for victims and survivors of Bondi massacre
item.description: A National Day of Reflection has been held on Sunday to commemorate victims of the Bondi mass shooting last week. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese also announced a review into federal intelligence agencies, as Sydney and Melbourne police warned of safety as an-immigration protests took place.

item.title: Nine killed, 10 injured in South Africa in second mass shooting this month
item.description: South Africa, Africa's biggest economy, has one of the world's highest murder rates, averaging about 60 a day.

item.title: Police charge man over alleged 'violent call to action' at beach
item.description: The man has been charged with using a carriage service to menace, harass, offend and publicly threaten violence on grounds of race or religion.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 22 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Israel authorises 19 new settlements in the West Bank
item.description: Israel’s move to authorise 19 West Bank settlements has reignited debate over security, annexation and the future of a Palestinian state. Supporters say it formalises existing outposts, while critics say it deepens occupation and fuels violence. The decision has also sharpened political divisions here in Australia over recognition and the two-state solution.

item.title: What is collective grief? How Australians are mourning the Bondi attack together
item.description: Following the Bondi Beach terror attack, people are coming together in Australia and around the world in grief.

item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he felt the "weight of responsibility" for the attack.

item.title: Bondi gunmen used guns in countryside, conducted 'reconnaissance', police allege
item.description: Court documents released to the media on Monday detail fresh allegations about the lead-up to the Bondi Beach terror attack.

item.title: As politicians debate a royal commission into the Bondi attack, what might it do?
item.description: Political and community leaders joined calls for a royal commission in the wake of the Bondi terror attack, rejected by the prime minister.

item.title: Russian general killed by car bomb in Moscow as Ukraine peace talks stall
item.description: A string of Russian military figures and high-profile supporters of Moscow's war in Ukraine have been assassinated during the nearly four-year-old conflict.

item.description: A string of Russian military figures and high-profile supporters of Moscow's war in Ukraine have been assassinated during the nearly four-year-old conflict.

item.title: 'Retreating' or playing the long game: Have the Greens faded from the spotlight?
item.description: In a sit-down with SBS News, Larissa Waters has admitted that while different from Adam Bandt, she's still fighting for the same values.

item.title: The simple Christmas food swaps that'll cut your grocery bill
item.description: Some Australians are looking for ways to lower their grocery bills, as the cost of living continues to bite. Here are the top tips from experts.

item.title: 'A part of the US': Trump appoints Greenland envoy, sparking diplomatic backlash
item.description: The US move revives sovereignty fears in the Arctic, as Denmark and Greenland warn strategic interests cannot justify territorial claims.

item.title: Morning News Bulletin 23 December 2025
item.description: New South Wales Parliament debates new laws after the Bondi attack; Denmark's disputes Donald Trump's new special envoy to Greenland; Nick Kyrgios misses out on the first round of wildcards for the Australian Open.

item.title: Australia in 2025: The events that shaped the nation
item.description: It has been a turbulent 12 months for Australians with unity in the community tested with the spillover of tensions from global conflicts. There was also milestone moments with the trial of mushroom cook Erin Patterson, and the ongoing impact of climate-driven weather extremes.

item.title: Ley stands by Wong criticism; Bowen calls Coalition words 'disgusting' amid Bondi debate
item.description: As Sussan Ley stands by her attack on Penny Wong over the Bondi tragedy, Chris Bowen has condemned Ley's remarks as politically charged.

item.title: Minns says protesters 'almost troll-like', unleashing 'forces they can't control'
item.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns appeared to link the behaviour of some protesters to 'extreme actions' in the community.

item.title: Capped numbers, shorter licences: How gun laws are set to change in NSW
item.description: NSW parliament has passed new firearms legislation in the wake of the Bondi Beach terror attack.

item.title: PM says steps taken to remove guns off the streets after Bondi attack | Midday Bulletin 23 December 2025
item.description: The Prime Minister says further steps are being taken to remove guns off the streets after the Bondi attack; new anti-protest measures in New South Wales face a legal challenge; and in cricket, Australia's squad for the Boxing Day Test announced.

item.title: Albanese government names groups it wants to crack down on amid anti-hate speech push
item.description: The Albanese government has revealed two groups in its sights for allegedly promoting hate and disunity.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 23 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Albanese recommends changes to MP travel perks following expenses controversy
item.description: Families of politicians would have their flights downgraded to economy class if the recommendations are implemented.

item.title: NSW parliament passes laws limiting protests, but will they be allowed to stand?
item.description: Laws to restrict the right to protest in New South Wales after the Bondi terror attack have passed the Parliament after a marathon sitting. A broad coalition of groups has expressed strong opposition, characterising the reforms as overreach and a serious threat to democracy. A constitutional challenge has been announced but the government is standing firm, setting the stage for a High Court challenge.

item.title: NSW Premier defends new anti-protest measures after Bondi shooting | Evening News Bulletin 23 December 2025
item.description: The New South Wales Premier defends new anti-protest measures after the Bondi shooting; the federal government says reforms are responding to the motive and method of Bondi attackers; the vice-captain of the Australian Women's Cricket Team admits she is going through the toughest period of her career.

item.title: Double demerits: What are the holiday road rules in place in your state?
item.description: In some parts of Australia, double demerits have arrived.

item.title: US, Venezuela edge closer to serious confrontation
item.description: The United States and Venezuela are edging closer to a serious diplomatic confrontation, after the US seized two oil tankers linked to the Venezuelan government in international waters, with a third now under pursuit. Venezuela accuses the US of piracy and an illegal naval blockade, as pressure mounts on the country's already sanctioned oil industry, with both Iran and China stating matters could spiral out of control.

item.title: This country has been crowned the world's 'happiest' for decades. Experts reveal why
item.description: Some experts suggest Denmark's happiness success is due to a focus on learning compassion, empathy and human connection at an early age.

item.title: ASX hits six week high as gold reaches another record
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Jamie Hannah from VanEck to find out what's driving the market as the Santa Rally continues.

item.title: 'Deeply loved': Former federal MP Katie Allen honoured after dying at age 59
item.description: The former Liberal MP revealed in May that she had been diagnosed with a rare and aggressive form of cancer known as cholangiocarcinoma.

item.title: Christmas Day weather extremes across Australia
item.description: Severe storms threaten Queensland, Melbourne will be cool and WA braces for extreme heat and bushfire warnings on Christmas Day.

item.title: Your guide to holiday trading hours across Australia
item.description: What's open this holiday season? Supermarket, retail, liquor, bank and medical trading hours across Australia.

item.title: Morning News Bulletin 24 December 2025
item.description: New South Wales parliament passes gun and protest laws prompted by the Bondi attack; Russia launches large-scale attacks across 13 regions of Ukraine; Pat Cummins to miss the remaining Tests of the Ashes series.

item.title: Turning points: what defined the world in 2025
item.description: 2025 has been a huge year for geopolitics, natural disasters and a changing of the guard at the top levers of international power and influence. We look back at the key moments.

item.title: Israeli president's planned post-Bondi-attack visit to Australia draws mixed reaction
item.description: While mainstream Jewish organisations have welcomed Isaac Herzog's recently announced visit to Australia, others have expressed dismay.

item.title: How one phone call cost Vicky $47,000
item.description: With Australia introducing world-first scam prevention legislation earlier this year, we hear from people who are seeking justice.

item.title: Minns defends 'extraordinary measures' after protest and gun laws pass
item.description: NSW has passed sweeping legislation tightening gun laws and granting police expanded powers to restrict public protests following the Bondi attack.

item.title: New Epstein records allege Trump flew on his jet 'many more times' than reported
item.description: A new batch of documents related to Jeffrey Epstein has been released by the US justice department.

item.title: Bondi heroes to be recognised in special honours list, Albanese announces
item.description: The prime minister says the awards will be announced next year.

item.title: Not all sunglasses protect you from eye damage. Here's how to spot the difference
item.description: Some sunglasses can put you at risk of eye damage. Here's how to tell the difference.

item.title: Meet the people helping clear Santa's flight path for smooth sleighing
item.description: The Peterson Space Force Base in the US city of Colorado Springs is normally busy tracking military targets. But this Christmas, it has another important mission: following the progress of Santa across the world on Christmas Eve. The North American Aerospace Defence Command - NORAD - has been doing this important work for the past 70 years.

item.title: UK national facing deportation for alleged display of Nazi symbols, Burke confirms
item.description: The news comes after a South African man had his visa cancelled in November for taking part in a neo-Nazi rally.

item.title: NSW Premier welcomes passage of gun control laws | Midday News Bulletin 24 December 2025
item.description: NSW Premier welcomes passage of gun control laws in state's upper house; The US and Iran trade barbs at the UN Security Council over nuclear talks; And in sport, Strong winds predicted for the start of the Sydney to Hobart yacht race.

item.title: As Christmas comes, Ukraine faces destruction and diplomacy
item.description: As Ukraine approaches another wartime Christmas, the contrast between diplomacy and destruction could hardly be sharper. While Kyiv says it has strengthened draft peace proposals in talks with the United States, Russia has launched one of its largest combined drone and missile attacks of the year, striking homes, power infrastructure and front-line towns.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 24 December 2025
item.description: A daily news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: US economy expands more than expected as local ASX Santa rally hits snag
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Mathan Somasundram from Deep Data Analytics about the better than expected US GDP result and what it means for interest rates, plus a look ahead to 2026 on the markets.

item.title: PM announces special honours list for Bondi massacre heroes | Evening News Bulletin 24 December 2025
item.description: The Prime Minister announces special honours list for Bondi massacre heroes; Palestinian officials denounce new Israeli settlements in occupied West Bank; And in sport, Shane Warne's memory and legacy to be honored at first Ashes Test at the MCG since his untimely death.

item.title: A seat at the table: How charities are fighting Christmas loneliness
item.description: As Australians prepare to celebrate Christmas, charities across the country are stepping in to support those most at risk of loneliness and isolation during the holiday season. Wesley Mission is hosting a free Christmas Day lunch to bring together people from all walks of life, while disability and community services work to ensure vulnerable Australians are not left without care or connection over the end of year shutdown.

item.title: 'Impossibly high threshold': Northern Territory bail laws facing High Court challenge
item.description: An Aboriginal legal service in the NT will launch a challenge to laws it says undermine fundamental legal principles.

item.title: How Australia's migrant communities put their own spin on Christmas
item.description: Around the world, and in migrant communities across Australia, a diverse range of customs give Christmas a unique flavour.

item.title: Why Christmas can be lonely — and how charities are working to change that
item.description: Christmas can be a challenging time for some. These groups are working to bring community to those who need it.

item.title: Ukraine indicates troop withdrawals in new proposed peace deal
item.description: The US-backed proposal stops short of recognising seized territory as Russian, though future Ukrainian withdrawals remain on the table.

item.title: WA Man charged over antisemitic posts on social media | Morning Bulletin 25 December 2025
item.description: Western Australia man charged over antisemitic posts on social media, Ukrainian forces have withdrawn from the embattled eastern town of Siversk, And in cricket Ben Stokes defends England as Ashes partying claims investigated

item.title: US issues visa bans for five Europeans involved in technology regulation
item.description: An EU spokesperson said it would seek answers from the United States about the "unjustified measures".

item.title: A heroine, a monster and true love - the new genre that's overturned the book world
item.description: It's not science fiction, but it has elements. It's not romance, but it touches the heart. It's not fantasy but don't be surprised if you encounter a werewolf or an elf. It's the new literary craze which is taking the book world by storm, driven by millions of fans on the social media platform TikTok. It's called romantasy.

item.title: The full beauty of Lake St Clair's depths is revealed
item.description: Lake St Clair is surrounded by Tasmania's Wilderness World Heritage area and was carved out by glaciers over millions of years. It's around twice as deep as Bass Strait, but Australia's deepest lake has never been fully mapped. Until now: CSIRO scientists have produced the first 3D map of the underwater landscape, confirming the vast depth of the natural wonder.

item.title: US officials uncover another million documents potentially linked to Epstein
item.description: It comes a week after hundreds of thousands of Epstein files were made public, many of which were redacted, angering both Republicans and Democrats.

item.title: Australian Christian leaders share Christmas message of ‘light’ and ‘hope’
item.description: Christian leaders from across Australia have delivered their Christmas messages, saying light will overcome darkness in the wake of the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: Protests banned in greater Sydney for 14 days | Midday Bulletin 25 December 2025
item.description: NSW Police Commissioner bans protests in greater Sydney for 14 days, Pope Leo calls for ceasefire in all conflicts during Christmas, Australia opts for pace-only attack in Boxing Day Test as spinner left out.

item.title: NSW Police invoke new powers to restrict Sydney protests for two weeks
item.description: NSW Police have imposed temporary limits on public gatherings under emergency laws passed in response to the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: How to safely store your Christmas leftovers and avoid food poisoning
item.description: If your Christmas feast has finished and you see large portions of food untouched on your table, you might only have a couple of hours to keep them.

item.title: 'Evil presence': PM condemns suspected antisemitic firebombing of a car in Melbourne
item.description: Detectives in Melbourne are investigating a suspicious antisemtic fire on Christmas Day.

item.description: Thousands line up for community Christmas lunches around the country; A car burned in a suspected antisemitic arson attack in Melbourne; 129 boats preparing for this year's Sydney to Hobart yacht race.

item.title: Ready for take-off? Here's how international travel is changing in 2026
item.description: From fresh international routes to new digital identity requirements, here's what you need to know about heading overseas next year.

item.title: Burnt out from 2025? Here's how to actually rest over the break
item.description: December can be a stressful time of year, and not everyone returns to work refreshed after the festive season.

item.title: 'Shared longing for peace': King Charles praises Bondi heroes in Christmas message
item.description: King Charles has spoken about overcoming uncertainty and division in his annual Christmas address.

item.title: Pope Leo decries conditions for Palestinians in Gaza in first Christmas sermon
item.description: In an address from the balcony of St Peter's Basilica, the pontiff also called for an end to conflicts in Ukraine, Sudan, Thailand and Cambodia.

item.title: Renewed calls for a royal commission into antisemitism | Morning News Bulletin 26 December 2025
item.description: Renewed calls for a royal commission into antisemitism, Pope Leo the 14th urges an end to fighting in Gaza and Ukraine in his first Christmas address, The fourth Ashes Test to get underway.

item.title: Victoria Police name person of interest in Hanukkah car fire
item.description: Victoria Police is searching for a person of interest as part of its early investigation into a suspected arson attack in south-east Melbourne.

item.title: The hidden workforce behind Melbourne’s tram seats
item.description: Melbourne’s trams have been part of the city for more than 140 years. Almost half a million people ride them each day — but few know the story behind the seats they sit on.

item.title: Streaming surge reveals how Australia's internet usage is changing
item.description: New NBN data reveals how streaming, working from home and faster broadband are reshaping Australia's internet usage.

item.title: Türkiye arrests more than 100 suspected IS members over alleged terror plots, officials say
item.description: The group was allegedly planning attacks during Christmas and New Year's celebrations, particularly against non-Muslims.

item.title: Why the US struck IS targets in Nigeria, and why an expert says Trump is 'oversimplifying' it
item.description: Announcing the strikes, Trump claimed terrorists had been targeting Christians "at levels not seen for many years" in Nigeria.

item.description: Australians are expected to spend more on Boxing Day sales this year. Here's how to take

item.title: Investigations into suspected antisemitic attack in Melbourne | Midday News Bulletin 26 December 2025
item.description: Investigations continue into a suspected antisemitic attack in Melbourne; Australians warned about Boxing Day scams; And in sport, the 80th Sydney Hobart Yacht Race about to get underway.

item.title: Refugee hotline sees spike in calls for help after Bondi terror attack
item.description: A hotline supporting refugees who have fled war, violence and persecution has received a funding boost after the Bondi terror attack. Those running the hotline service in New South Wales says the funding will allow it to extend its reach nationally, supporting refugees as they navigate the ongoing effects of complex trauma and triggers of what happened at Bondi.

item.description: A daily news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Have an hour to spare these holidays? It could make a big difference to your retirement
item.description: Many Australians don’t know their super balance or how it’s invested — and the super industry says the holidays are a good time to change that.

item.title: Police call for information over Christmas Day arson attack | Evening News Bulletin 26 November 2025
item.description: Police appeal for information about a person of interest in the Christmas Day arson attack; Extreme weather warnings across the country; And in sport, LawConnect leads the fleet as the 80th annual Sydney to Hobart yacht race gets underway.

item.title: Shooting victims honoured as Sydney to Hobart crews pass Bondi Beach
item.description: Olympic swimming great Ian Thorpe was among those in the 129-strong fleet to pay tribute.

item.title: Trump says he ordered strikes against IS in Nigeria
item.description: President Donald Trump says the United States has launched a 'powerful and deadly' strike against IS in north-western Nigeria. Mr Trump described those killed as 'terrorist scum' who had been targeting and killing primarily innocent Christians.

item.title: Another election, 'no winner'? What’s at stake in Kosovo's snap vote
item.description: The Balkan country is headed to the polls on Sunday, after nearly a year of political deadlock that's caused "colossal damage" to its economy.
